stream_context.summary: Kaze primarily worked on creating and concepting assets for the craft-themed Course 14, discussing star ideas, level mechanics, and aesthetic choices. He also showcased recent progress on Course 13, including a mirror boss fight and cloud platforming, and tested its performance on original N64 hardware.

development_findings.summary: Course 14, the craft level, will feature interactive star challenges, such as carrying a crayon to a specific spot to physically draw a star onto a piece of paper.
development_findings.quote: There's a Luigi doodle... he says, if only I had a yellow crayon, I could draw a star... So you have to go find a yellow crayon, carry it there and draw the star.

development_findings.summary: The NPCs in Course 14 are intentionally designed as simple 'doodles' and 'robotic' figures, precluding any complex narrative for that level.
development_findings.quote: This course is going to be very simple and all the NPCs in this are going to be very robotic. And like, they're not real people. So we can't really make a story with it.

development_findings.summary: Kaze tested Course 13 on N64 hardware and found the framerate dropped to 25 FPS, concluding he can fix it by reducing the number of cloud models.
A key encounter in Course 13 is a fight against a Mirror Mario, showcasing a unique boss concept.
development_findings.quote: You fight Mirror Mario by kicking up here. Isn't that cool?

development_findings.summary: The release strategy involves an initial version compatible with emulators, followed by an N64-native version designed to push the hardware's limits and challenge emulator developers to keep pace.
development_findings.quote: My plan is we release version 1... and then 1.2 is only N64. Because at that point we have enough emulator compatibility that we can just say, fuck it, we're making an N64 game. And emulators will then technologically have to catch up with the game.

development_findings.summary: The team is brainstorming pun-based crayon brand names for textures in the craft level, with 'Craytendo,' 'Artendo,' and 'Koopa's Tail' as leading candidates.
development_findings.quote: We still need a funny crayon brand. Craytendo so far is the best one to me. Koopa Colors is number 2... Artendo is also a strong contender... Koopa's Tail. Yes, that's good.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is creating assets for Course 14, including reflective plastic cups, cardboard trees, and tilting platforms made of cardboard and toothpicks, focusing on a DIY craft aesthetic.
Kaze implemented a desk lamp in the skybox to act as the primary light source for Course 14, reinforcing the level's theme of being a craft project on a table.

context_findings.summary: Kaze holds a strong anti-advertisement philosophy, believing they add an unfair surcharge to products. He plans to subvert a potential Raid Shadow Legends sponsorship by pairing the ad read with four hours of esoteric content.
context_findings.quote: Generally, I never take sponsorships unless I can think of a way to like fuck them over.

context_findings.summary: Kaze advises aspiring game developers to rapidly create many small games to move through the initial learning curve and get the 'suckage out immediately'.
context_findings.quote: My advice to get people getting into game development is always make as many games as possible as fast as possible. So you learn because your first 100 games or so are just going to suck ass.

context_findings.summary: Kaze reflects on his past design philosophy for 'Lost Impact', stating his goal was to make it 'interesting' rather than 'fun', which led him to include every idea without filtering for quality to avoid feeling 'lazy'.
context_findings.quote: When I made Last Impact, really my thought was never can I make this fun, it was always just I have an idea, I'll put it in... I didn't want to be some lazy dude who doesn't put the things he wanted this game in.

context_findings.summary: Kaze challenges the common wisdom about N64 development, stating that after significant optimization, the RSP (graphics co-processor) is now the main bottleneck for his project, not the CPU.
context_findings.quote: The N64 CPU no longer is strong compared to the GPU because once you actually optimize the memory throughput, the RSP became the bottleneck, at least on my end.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's motivation for physical fitness is linked to his mental fitness and performance, having originally started working out to improve his reaction time for competitive gaming.
context_findings.quote: I just wanted to make sure I'm physically fit so I can be mentally fit.

context_findings.summary: Kaze lives in Canada with his wife Zeina and is frustrated with the lingering German bureaucracy from his home country.
Kaze is using ChatGPT to handle business negotiations for a potential sponsorship, sending its responses without reading them.
context_findings.quote: I legit just went to chat GPT and told it make me as much money as possible. And it just spat out that text and I just sent that to Raid Shadow Legends.

biobak.summary: Biobak significantly optimized Course 13 by removing 400 polygons, primarily by creating a better, lower-poly replacement for placeholder trees Kaze had made.
biobak.quote: Rearmament will increase a little, but so far main area has 400 fewer polis and a shit ton of materials and overall removed. Removed the trees around the area.

biobak.summary: Kaze anticipates that the visuals for the main area of Course 13 will be greatly improved once Biobak applies his artistic skills to it.
Biobak is currently working on preparing Course 1 for the upcoming public demo.

zeina.summary: Zeina is working on the outside area for Course 13.
She playtested the physics and movement in Course 13, and her positive experience gave Kaze confidence that the controls were intuitive.
Zeina contributed the idea 'Koopa Colors' for the crayon brand name in the craft level.
zeina.quote: Zeina was saying Koopa colors, but I think that might be a bit too long.

zeina.summary: Zeina is creating sketches for the game's overworld, which is planned to be 'Yoshi's fruit islands'.

key_stories.title: The AI-Negotiated Sponsorship
key_stories.summary: When faced with a sponsorship offer from a company he dislikes, Kaze decided to turn the negotiation process into an experiment. He outsourced the entire negotiation to ChatGPT and plans to deliver a maliciously compliant video that technically fulfills the contract while actively undermining its marketing value.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze received a sponsorship offer from Raid Shadow Legends, a product he does not respect and whose advertising model he dislikes.
key_stories.process: Instead of negotiating himself, Kaze used ChatGPT to generate responses aimed at maximizing profit, sending them without review. He also devised a plan for the sponsored video itself: a one-minute ad read followed by four hours of esoteric, monotonous content (every visible wall in Mario 64).
key_stories.outcome: The negotiation is ongoing, with Kaze finding the process of using an AI as his agent amusing. He has a clear plan to subvert the sponsorship's intent if it's accepted, aligning with his personal principles against intrusive advertising.
key_stories.key_quote: I legit just went to chat GPT and told it make me as much money as possible. And it just spat out that text and I just sent that to Raid Shadow Legends.

key_stories.title: The Evolution from 'Interesting' to 'Fun'
key_stories.summary: Kaze reflected on his journey as a game designer, contrasting his current approach with his work on 'Lost Impact.' He revealed his earlier motive was to implement every idea to feel productive, prioritizing 'interesting' over 'fun,' which led to many of the hack's infamous design quirks. This story highlights his growth and a more player-focused mindset now.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze's older ROM hack, 'Lost Impact,' was known for bizarre and sometimes frustrating design choices. He needed to articulate how his design philosophy has changed for the current project.
key_stories.process: During the stream, a viewer's comment prompted Kaze to reflect on his past work. He explained that his former process was to implement every single idea he had, without critique, to prove to himself he wasn't lazy. This resulted in a game filled with interesting but not always enjoyable mechanics.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze now possesses a more mature design philosophy. He understands the distinction between making a game 'interesting' versus 'fun' and is no longer driven by a fear of being 'lazy', allowing him to better filter ideas for the player's benefit.
key_stories.key_quote: When I made Last Impact, really my thought was never can I make this fun, it was always just I have an idea, I'll put it in. I just put the idea in when I had the idea... because I didn't want to be lazy.

key_stories.title: Battling the Framerate in the Clouds
key_stories.summary: Kaze demonstrated his iterative development process by testing Course 13 on N64 hardware live on stream. He identified a framerate drop, diagnosed the cause as excessive cloud models, and quickly formulated a solution. This practical example showed his problem-solving approach and reliance on real-hardware testing to validate design choices.
key_stories.challenge: After building a visually interesting cloud section for Course 13, Kaze was concerned about its performance on actual N64 hardware.
key_stories.process: Kaze used a flashcart to run the level on an N64 console in real-time. He observed the framerate dropping to 25 FPS in graphically intense areas and immediately diagnosed the problem as too many cloud polygons. His proposed solution was to simply reduce the cloud density.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze has a clear, simple solution to the performance problem and is confident he can achieve his 30 FPS target. The incident also revealed another optimization from Biobak, showing how team collaboration is improving level performance.
key_stories.key_quote: I want at least 30 FPS... 25 there. I can very easily increase the FPS by just reducing the amount of clouds. That would be no issue at all.

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned that a contributor named Sauraen is working on optimizing the RSP (Reality Signal Processor) microcode. This was presented as a significant technical undertaking.
questions: Who is Sauraen and what is their role on the team?
What specific limitations of the default N64 RSP code is this new work trying to solve?
How will these optimizations tangibly impact the game? Will it allow for more complex geometry, better lighting, or just higher framerates?
Kaze, you mentioned the RSP is now your bottleneck. How does Sauraen's work change what you thought was possible for this project?

open_questions.context: Zeina is creating sketches for the overworld, described as 'Yoshi's fruit islands,' where the player explores 'deeper and deeper into the island.' This suggests a cohesive, progressive world design.
questions: Zeina, what is the core concept behind the 'fruit islands' overworld? What's the story or feeling you want to convey?
How does the overworld design evolve as the player progresses?
What was the collaborative process between you and Kaze for designing the overworld? How do you turn sketches into a functional game space?
Are there any unique mechanics or secrets planned specifically for the overworld itself?

open_questions.context: Kaze explained that for his old hack 'Lost Impact,' his goal was to make things 'interesting,' not 'fun.' He now seems to have a more refined philosophy.
questions: How do you define 'fun' versus 'interesting' in your design process today?
What is your current 'filter' for ideas? Can you give an example of an idea for RTYI that you discarded because it was interesting but not fun?
How does the rest of the team, like Biobak and Zeina, provide feedback to ensure new mechanics are fun to play?
Looking back at Lost Impact, is there one specific 'bizarre decision' you're secretly still proud of, even if it wasn't 'fun'?

open_questions.context: Kaze stated a release plan where an N64-only version will eventually be released specifically to force emulators to 'catch up' with the game's technical demands.
questions: What is the core motivation behind this strategy of pushing emulators to adapt? Is it about authenticity, a technical challenge, or something else?
What specific N64 features do you plan to use that you expect will be difficult for current emulators to handle?
What is your relationship with the emulator development community? Do you see this as a challenge or a collaboration?
How will this affect the average player who may not have N64 hardware?

open_questions.context: A viewer mentioned a negative interaction with another ROM hacker ('brodute'), leading Kaze to comment on 'echo chambers' in the hacking community and their different standards for enjoyment (e.g. 6/8 red coins).
questions: You mentioned an 'echo chamber' in the hacking community. Can you elaborate on the different 'paradigms' of what makes a hack enjoyable?
How do you balance creating a game that appeals to the hardcore hacking community versus a broader audience?
You described 8 red coins as a 'cheap way' to make a star. What makes for a creative, well-designed star in your opinion?
